intro: Sinapis pubescens var. tenuirostris, commonly known as the narrow-beaked mustard, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually yellow or whitish, and it produces small, cylindrical seed pods that release seeds when mature. This variety is often found in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to thrive in temperate climates.
